title: Judicial Review of South Yorkshire Police

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
I understand that data exists related to a judicial review of South Yorkshire Police, whether speculative or not.
Please provide any and all information related to any reference to the judicial review of South Yorkshire Police.
To aid you in identifying such data it will be related to the Streets Ahead  contract.
Yours faithfully,
Mr. Buxton

Dear Mr Buxton,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Judicial review of
South Yorkshire police which we received on 28/10/2022.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
We are aware that John Mothersole, former chief executive of the council,
refers to a judicial review of South Yorkshire Police in his evidence to
the Independent Street Tree Inquiry on 27 October 2022. He said he
dismissed the idea, around 1 hour 9 minutes into his evidence
here: [1]
https://sheffield.public-i.tv/core/porta...
We can find no record of this idea in our legal case management system nor
the records published to date by the Street Tree
Archive: [2]
https://www.sheffield.gov.uk/libraries-a...
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [3]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[4]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council

Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Mr Buxton
Our reference: Internal Review – FOI – 2022/23 – 0864
We apologise for not meeting our deadline of 6 January 2023. Our original
deadline was 28 December 2022. However, we overlooked the provision in
section 10 of the Act to extend the deadline for the request by 20 working
days.
Section 10(3) of the Freedom of information Act 2000 enables an authority
to extend the 20 working day limit up to a ‘reasonable’ time in any case
where:
•         it requires more time to determine whether or not the balance of
the public interest lies in maintaining an exemption; or
•         it needs further time to consider whether it would be in the
public interest to confirm or deny whether the information is held.
Sheffield City Council has not yet reached a decision on whether or not
the balance of the public interest lies in maintaining an exemption under
section 42 for legal professional privilege and, as a result, we will not
be able to respond to your request in full by the statutory disclosure
date.
Under section 45(1) of the Freedom of information Act 2000 (FOIA), the
Minister for the Cabinet Office has issued a  [1]Code of Practice which
provides guidance to public bodies on request handling.
Section 4.6 of that guidance states that it is best practice for an
extension to be no more than a further 20 working days, although, in some
circumstances, a longer extension may be appropriate.
Consequently, we are extending the deadline by an additional 20 working
days until 26 January 2023 at the latest, but we will endeavour to provide
a response as soon as possible.
Yours sincerely
Sheffield City Council

Dear Mr Buxton
We apologise for the third week running for failing to provide you with
our internal review of your request for information regarding a judicial
review of South Yorkshire Police
.
Your original request was dated 28/10/22.
We replied on 25 November 2022, and you complained about our response on
26 November 2022.
We gave you a deadline of 28 December 2022 by which time we proposed to
provide an internal review.
On 9 January 2023 we informed you that we had overlooked extending the
deadline for our response by a month, as we wanted to conduct a public
interest test for legally privileged information. Section 10 of the Act
enables a public authority to do this – albeit before the deadline has
passed.
On the new deadline of 26 January 2023, and then on 8 February 2023 via
the Chief Executive’s office, we advised you of delays.
Today, we cannot reply as this week has been half-term, which has slowed
everything down. Our hope is that with the return to business as usual
next week, our response to you can be finalised.
It would be churlish to suggest that a further fortnight’s extension
beyond 26 January 2023 because the request is complex, would have been
justified, meaning a response today would only be a week late. So we are
not going to rely upon this provision in the section 45 Code of Practice
regarding internal reviews.
Whilst Robert Burns wrote that, “A [person]’s reach should exceed his
grasp, or what's a heaven for”, we would have to gently confirm that our
hand can only hold so much at a time. Your request will have its day.
We understand your frustration, even though you must know that we have
every intention of replying. We are very mindful of deadlines, but
inevitably a small number of requests just cannot be fitted into the legal
deadlines. The Information Commissioner’s Office recognises this reality
regarding as “good”, a performance where 95% of internal reviews are
responded to within the deadline.
We ask you appreciate how demanding it is to run a council of this size,
in which FOI is just one of many competing priorities.
Keep the faith. Our response will be with you no later than it can be
avoided.
Sheffield City Council

Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Mr Buxton
Thank you for your request for an internal review relating to the proposal
for a Judicial review of South Yorkshire police, which we received on
26/11/2022. We were due to reply by 28 December 2022 but postponed this
due to annual leave until 6 January 2023. On 9 January 2023 we said to you
that we had made a mistake by not extending the deadline under section 10
of the Act by 20 working days, as we had legally privileged information,
which required the application of the public interest test. Our new
deadline was 26 January 2023. We have kept you updated about our delays
since but apologise again for falling short of the legal requirement to
answer on time. This has been due to workloads.
Your complaint was about our failure to locate any information relating to
a judicial review of South Yorkshire Police by Sheffield City Council; and
to rely on an answer John Mothersole, the former chief executive, gave Sir
Mark Lowcock at a public hearing of the Independent Inquiry into the
Street Tree Dispute on 27 October 2022. Mr Mothersole told Sir Mark
Lowcock (about 69 minutes into his evidence) that when the idea was
floated of judicially review the police, arising from disquiet that they
were giving the council less attention than they had, he dismissed this
option.
We accept your complaint. Our search was not comprehensive. We have
located information, which is in scope.
This information is legally privileged under section 42(1) of the Act. The
type of privilege within the concept of legal professional privilege in
this information is advice privilege, which applies where no litigation is
in progress or contemplated. It covers confidential communications between
the client and lawyer, made for the main purpose of seeking or giving
legal advice. This helps to ensure complete fairness in legal proceedings.
The client was the council.
Section 42 is a qualified exemption, subject to the public interest test.
The council must consider whether the public interest in maintaining the
exemption outweighs the public interest in disclosure. The general public
interest inherent in this exemption will always be strong due to the
importance of the principle behind LPP: safeguarding openness in all
communications between client and lawyer to ensure access to full and
frank legal advice, which in turn is fundamental to the administration of
justice.
The public interest in disclosing the information is the assumption in
favour of disclosure and the rationale behind the assumption (ie
accountability, transparency, furthering public debate etc). The
Information Commissioner’s Office advises that additional weight may be
added to this factor if either of these issues are relevant in the
particular case:
a large amount of money involved; a large number of people affected; lack
of transparency in the public authority's actions. In this case, the
advice was sought from a barrister, as part of a range of legal advice the
council commissioned. There was no abnormal cost; it did not proceed so
did not affect a large number of people; but it is a matter of public
interest in the dispute about street trees. Sir Mark Lowcock did publicly
reveal that there had been consideration of the idea in council circles.
We have therefore decided that on balance it is in the public interest to
disclose the information.
We have extracted this information from a ‘Note on enforcing High Court
injunction’ some legal advice provided by a barrister to SCC on 9 October
2017.
1. We have been asked to provide a note to the Council on how,
practically, to enforce the injunction Orders granted by Males Jon 17
August 2017.
2. The brief background to this note is that, since 25 September 2017,
protestors have resumed carrying out direct action within safety zones.
This has frustrated tree-felling on a number of occasions. Where these
individuals are known to the Council and/or Amey, or can subsequently be
identified, committal applications have been or will be brought. There
are, however, a number of examples of individuals entering safety zones
who have and will escape identification. There is also, to date, one
example of an individual within a safety zone wearing a mask. (1) We
understand that there is real concern that Unknown Protestors will
continue to disrupt tree-felling.
3. To the extent that Unknown Protestors cannot be identified, it would be
impossible to issue committal proceedings against them in the High Court.
In respect of this category of protestors, therefore, the Council needs to
take extra steps. In light of how much money the Council has spent
obtaining the injunction Orders, and in the event that other steps are
ineffective, we advise that at least one of the following extra steps must
be taken.
4. These extra steps are:
a. Urging the police to arrest Unknown Protestors and, if that fails,
sending a pre-action protocol letter to the police threatening a judicial
review of their decision not to arrest; and/or,
b. Using reasonable force (whether Amey or the Council) to prevent Unknown
Protestors from entering safety ones or removing Unknown Protestors
already within safety zones.
(a) Escalating matters with the police
5. We consider it essential that the Council steps up its communications
with the police and urges the police to make arrests. If necessary, the
Council should threaten to bring judicial review proceeding against the
police.
6. Previously, the police has said that it would not take action until the
civil process had been exhausted. The police had also variously said that
no offences were being committed and/or there was no public interest in
prosecution.
7. The civil process has now been concluded - at great financial cost to
the Council - with a High Court injunction having been granted. Males J
found that those carrying out direct action are committing at least one
criminal offence: s303 of the Highways Act 1980. (2) Moreover, given the
findings of Males J, it would also follow that a criminal offence contrary
to s241 of the Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992
is being committed by the protestors.
8. In this light, it is difficult to see how the police can justify its
stance of inaction. This is in the circumstances that: (i) the High Court
has confirmed that the protestors are committing at least one criminal
offence; (ii) the High Court has decided that direct action - and the harm
caused by it - exceeds the lawful ambit of the right to protest; and,
(iii) notwithstanding the substantial reasons necessitating the High Court
injunction, its enforcement is proving difficult due to shortcomings in
the civil process.
9. As a result, the factors previously relied upon by the police no longer
stand up to scrutiny. The Council should urge upon the police, in no
uncertain terms, that it must take action and that failure to do is an
unlawful abdication of its duties and powers.
10. In the event that the police refuses to take action, the Council
should prepare and serve a Pre-Action
Protocol Letter. This would inform the police that the Council intends to
bring judicial review proceedings against it unless action is taken.
11. The Council's argument would be that:
i. Protestors standing inside safety zones are committing criminal
offences;
ii. The police has power to arrest them, pursuant to s24 of the Police and
Criminal Evidence Act 1984;
iii. The police's policy decision of not arresting protestors within
safety zones is unlawful in that the police have failed to take into
account the relevant considerations that:
Those carrying out direct action are committing criminal offences;
The direct action exceeds the lawful ambit of the right to protest; as
found by Males J, the conduct of the protestors cannot be justified in
light of the harm being caused to the public interest; and,
The Council cannot enforce the High Court injunction against Unknown
Protestors; and,
iv. The High Court ought to grant a declaration to that effect.
12. Unfortunately, it would be very unlikely for a court to order a police
authority to make these arrests: see, for example, R v Chief Constable of
Devan and Cornwall ex p Central Electricity Generating Board [1982) QB 458
(CA). Nonetheless, it is hoped that the threat of a judicial review, and
even bringing the judicial review itself to obtain a declaration, would
encourage the police to take action.
(1) I will refer to these two types of protestors as "Unknown Protestors".
(2) Paras 66-67 of his judgment.
This concludes our review. If you are still dissatisfied with our
response, you can contact the Information Commissioner for a decision:
